item.title: UCTM professor participates in UN Committee for the Space
item.description: Xu Yi, professor and researcher at the State Lunar and Planetary Science Laboratory at Macao University of Science and Technology (UCTM), first participated as a member of the Chinese delegation of the United Nations Committee (UN) for the outside space. The body concerned is called the United Nations Committee for the peaceful uses of the outer space (Copuos) and held its 68th session in Vienna, Austria. Xu Yi participated in the discussion of themes such as “Space and Water” and “Space and Sustainable Development”. According to official information, “the participation of an academic of Macao in Copuos reflects the support of the central government to the scientific and technological development of mashes”, which demonstrates “the success” of the practice of “one country, two systems” in the territory. In turn, Xu Yi said that "the state laboratory will continue to contribute to Chinese spatial exploration, strengthening the role of Macao in the national scientific advance." This State Laboratory was approved by the Ministry of Science and Technology of China, and was officially established in 2018. In turn, the State Lunar and Planetary Science Laboratory of the University of Science and Technology of Macau is the only Chinese national laboratory dedicated to astronomy and planetary sciences. Its creation, according to the same official sources, "aligns with the spatial exploration strategy, promoting technological innovation in the great Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macau Bay and raising the scientific level of Macao." Currently, the laboratory has over 40 experts and a research team with over 200 members. With history Copuos was founded on the UN in 1959 and aims to “establish principles and regulations for the peaceful use of the outer space, to promote international cooperation in this area and study scientific and legal issues related to spatial exploration”, explains the same note, which also accounts for events held in the context of this meeting of Copuos. It is "One Humanity, Infinite Frontiers" [a humanity, infinite borders], organized by China and that took place at the UN headquarters in Vienna, being an exhibition that celebrated the "20 years of the Chinese Lunar Exploration Program." Xu Yi participated in this event and shared “The Trajectory of the State Laboratory in supporting the Chinese National Space Agency”.

item.title: Gastronomy Party brings chefs Jordy Navarra and Varun Totlani to the fishermen's dock

item.title: Commerce | Supermarket closure is “strategic adjustment”
item.description:
IP Sio Man, president of the Vang Kei Hong Commercial Agency, discourages the recent closure of some supermarkets in the territory and states that it is only an “adjustment” in the commercial strategy, related to poor location of spaces and the necessary reduction in the number of establishments
The closing of supermarkets in Macao is not a sign of a major economic crisis, but of a necessary trade adjustment by the brands. Who says it is IP Sio Man, president of the commercial agency Vang Kei Hong, who yesterday in a public event said that the recent closure of these commercial spaces was just a "strategic adjustment" by the companies. “Firstly, when we talk about closing we realize that these are individual cases. Then we have a large proportion of supermarkets [by number of inhabitants in Macao]. There are supermarket chains that are adjusting because they opened on the wrong places and simply closed and changed to other zones.” The official, who spoke to journalists on the sidelines of the company's 50th anniversary, said the market has changed and that there are some economic sectors that are reducing the number of spaces, not just supermarkets. "Macao has about 680,000 inhabitants, but about 100,000 people do not usually live in the territory. The [supermarkets] number is too excessive, and the situation is similar in markets," he said. Vang Kei Hong provides foods and goods to retailers, restaurants, hotels and resorts. Its president also set the example of banks, who are closing branches. In your opinion, this does not mean a scenario of economic retreat, but simply a strategy change, given that there are more and more online services that customers can enjoy. Neighborhoods suffer Asked about the panorama of the economy in the relationship with the social sector in the first half, IP Sio Man argued that the results are varied, with tourism to record a breakthrough. However, he said that traders in community neighborhoods, where there is less tourism, continue to suffer from the lack of customers. For this reason, IP Sio Man argues that Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) themselves have to change their commercial strategy. The businessman believes that in the second half of this year, the business environment can improve, as Hong Kong has revealed prosperous growth, and Macau has also had a larger number of tourists. IP SIO MAN, therefore, indicated that SMEs have to focus on ways to attract tourists consumption. "I don't think it's a matter that tourists don't want to spend money. They just consume products that guarantee them the best cost-benefit ratio," he added. One of the examples referred to by the entrepreneur is the bitter tea brand in the interior of China Wanglaoji, which registered an increase in sales to about 30 containers, while in previous years sales were only one digit.

item.title: Elections | At least 32 crimes oblige to serve a prison sentence
item.description:
The electoral law requires the application of effective arrest penalties that may vary between one month and more than 10 years. One of the cases in which convicts even need to spend time in Coloane's prison is the crime of public incentive to abstention, blank vote or null vote
The law provides for at least 32 crimes that always oblige to serve a prison sentence. One of these crimes is the public incentive to abstention, blank vote or null vote, which causes a penalty ranging from one month to three years. According to the general rules of the Penal Code, when someone is convicted of committing a crime there is a possibility that the penalty is suspended for a period from one year to five years. In order for the penalty to be suspended, the law determines that the conviction cannot exceed three years in prison. This period is also time usually considered as a reference for the definition of small crime or a crime that is not serious. However, the electoral law, through article 147, abdicates the regime of suspension of prison penalties, which means that the convicts, under normal conditions, will always spend at least one month in Coloane's prison establishment. The law divides the crime in which it abdicates the suspension of penalty into “crimes related to the organization of the electoral process”, “crimes related to the electoral campaign” and “crimes related to suffrage and investigation”. The list of crimes related to the organization of the electoral process includes six offenses and in at least five of them the application of a prison sentence is mandatory, as with the person who accepts to be recognized as a candidate when he does not gather the legal conditions, or when the coercion or fraudulent devices are resorted to condition the will to participate, or not, in an application committee, in the designation of the vote in the staff and the decision of the decision A person is a candidate, or not, to the elections. Election campaign One of the most controversial questions in the elections is the election campaign period and the ban on campaign activities before the legal period, which this year starts on August 30 and extends until September 12. Earlier this week, the chairman of the Legislative Assembly Electoral Affairs Committee (Caeal), Seng Ioi Man, warned that despite not being received complaints about illicit, the authorities are attentive to potential infringements. The law provides for seven campaign -related crimes, but most, four in seven, admits the application of a penalty of a fine, so that the prison sentence will not always be applicable. However, in case there is fraudulent deviation correspondence from Caeal, slanderous denunciation of the crimes provided for in this law or electoral propaganda less than 100 meters from the vote assemblies, punishment always undergoes prison for periods ranging from one month to eight years. Broader crimes It is in the section of “crimes related to suffrage and determination” that the law has the largest number of illicit situations, with a total of 23 crimes. Among the 23 illicit, in four is allowed to apply a penalty of fine, in addition to prison sentence, but only in certain circumstances. In most crimes planned, 18, it is always mandatory to apply a prison sentence that varies between one month and about 10 years and 8 months, depending on the crime committed. Some of these crimes are specific and aim at security forces, as with forced entry at voting assemblies, and voting meeting for fraud at the time of counting the votes. However, there are also crimes that can be committed by any citizen. It is in this category that is the public incentive to abstention, blank or null vote, which causes a penalty ranging from one month to three years in prison. The same can happen when, within the scope of work, someone threatens a worker with a professional sanction for the coercion targeted to reveal his sense of vote, or vote based on this coercion.

item.title: Checks | Nick Lei calls for postponement of changes for one year
item.description:
The deputy linked to the community of Fujian finds it unfair that the imposition of staying 183 days in Macao to receive the pecuniary check was implemented in relation to 2024, giving no opportunity to residents who live out to fulfill the obligation. Nick Lei argues that it is possible to verify the days of stay in the territory in the single account
Deputy Nick Lei thinks that the changes to the requirements of assignment of the pecuniary reimbursement plan in economic development, known as a pecuniary check, were hasty, harming the beneficiaries. "The measures were implemented too hurriedly and the imperfect application brought many inconveniences and obstacles to the residents," said the legislator in a written interpretation, adding that when the news was released "triggered discussions and social controversy." The number two on the list of the Fujian parliamentary bench in the next September 14 legislatures suggested to the government that it “fully consider the impact and inconvenience” of measures or policy adjustments, “taking into account the real needs of residents”. The deputy cites complaints of residents who criticized the hasty form as the changes were applied, which will take into account of the days past in Macau last year, "which makes many residents of Macao who live abroad to choose to be in Macau according to their personal will." Therefore, Nick Lei asks the Executive to Sam Hou Fai to consider postponing one year the implementation of the new measures to assign the cash check. Lifelong The deputy also suggests to the government to add functionality to the mobile application single account, allowing residents to verify the number of days of stay in Macau. Nick Law currently stresses, this registration can only be "processed at service posts or self-service kiosks." The introduction of functionality in mobile application not only promotes administrative efficiency, but reduces treatment costs and inconvenience for residents, the deputy says. The need to apply personally, through a third party or post documents to prove that if you are in an exception situation for those who have not spent 183 days in Macao also motivated complaints of Nick Law, who would like to see the whole process to be treated in the single account. Despite the suggestions, the deputy points out that "it is necessary to optimize and improve the policy based on maintaining the original intention, so that public funds can be used accurately."

item.title: Cape Verde | Évora family, between Macau and the rest of the world
item.description:
Tomorrow are 50 years of Cape Verde's independence, the country from which the first levada of the Évora family came out in the 1940s, towards Macao, where he won roots. Nowadays, only one member of the family remains in the territory, the cardiologist Mário Évora
There were once a dozen Évoras in Macao, where they arrived in the 1940s, but only Mario Évora resists, with the family repeating the migrations that mark both Cape Verde and the Macanese. "We have been between eight and ten Évoras in Macau," Sports Medicine expert Humberto Évora told Lusa from Lisbon, where he has lived since he renovated. The maternal grandparents of Humberto (the last of the family to be born in Cape Verde) and Mário (the first to be born in Macau) arrived in the east in the late 1940s, with five of the couple's six children. A year later, the daughter who had stayed with her husband in Cape Verde came to Macau, already with baby Humberto. The initial plan was for two years, but the couple ended up three decades and have three more children: Mario, Rui and Maria Helena. In 1971, it was the turn of Humberto and Mário to leave to study medicine in Lisbon, but not without a great fright linked to the colonial war that had lasted a decade ago. "As we went to the university we could postpone military inspection, but the papers did not come from Macao and we risk being considered refractory," said Humberto. The situation resolved, but Mario admitted to Lusa the fear of the mobilization. "We had this persecution, we had to go through the year not to go with the sides in the war," he explained. “The Shock” in Lisbon Upon arrival in Lisbon, “we were soon welcomed and integrated into the Cape Verdean student community,” said Humberto, at a time of student agitation and politics. "There were periods when it was almost daily, manifestations of students against the regime, the shock police enter the canteen inside and give some suckling," said Mario. Humberto admitted that "it was a shock, for those who came from Macau, where there was little political culture and the colonial war was seen as a struggle against terrorists." In a summer, the young man, who was integrated into a Cape Verdean group of intervention music, left with a friend "to the overseas ride out of guitar on his back." “I always remember the first time in France, that I saw the colonial war described on the contrary on television, the struggle for the liberation of a colonial power of occupation,” said Humberto. Independence When the two brothers finished the medical course, the independence of Cape Verde, on July 5, 1975, led them to the root return. "There was a movement of many of our colleagues to contribute to a new country, which was beginning to take the first steps," said Mario, then a formed cardiologist. Also because, recalled Humberto, some of the friends of Lisbon had, however, became members of the Government of Cape Verde. "There was this possibility, but the return to Macao, a place where it had spent so long, was natural," he explained. “I was born in Cape Verde, I spent part of my life in Portugal, I grew up in Macao, I am also Macaense. I am a citizen of the world,” said Humberto. Macanese are a Euro-Asian community, most of which Lusodescendants, with roots in Macau, although many have emigrated, due to the economic situation or fear created by the transition from Portugal Administration to China in 1999. From the Évora brothers, Rui, engineer, left before the transition to Cape Verde, where he even worked on the project of the Hotel-Casino that Macau's businessman David Chow built on the beach, but was inaugurated. The younger sister, Maria Helena, a documentary science expert who has even worked in the Macao Historical Archive, is currently in the City Council of Oeiras. The children “are all out” between the United Kingdom, Cape Verde and Portugal, said Mario. "Now the world is smaller and it is going where there are opportunities," he said. Humberto also faces migrations "as a natural process, not only for Cape Verdeans, but even to the Macanese." Nothing that has prevented the two brothers from keeping their ties with the archipelago. Humberto divides the time between Portugal and Cape Verde, and has been the official doctor of Cape Verdean sports for decades to the main international competitions. Mario was one of the founders-and president for ten years-of the Macau-Cabo Green Friendship Association. "We had here Ildo Lobo, Tito Paris, and my cousin," said the cardiologist, before taking a break and adds, with a smile: "Cesaria Évora."

item.title: City of Dreams | The magic of the fashion world in the Horst P. Horst lens
item.description:
Lovers of fashion and beauty can visit, by September, an exhibition dedicated to the work of fashion photographer Horst P. Horst patent at City of Dreams. “Horst: Style Photographer” is an “iconic fashion photography” exhibition held in conjunction with the prestigious Albert Museum London
It was born at the time when fashion was almost an art form, taking a long time to democratize and reach stores and people. This more classic side of fabrics and seams was certainly eternalized in the photograph by Horst P. Horst, which became one of the great fashion photographers and was born in 1906, named Horst Paul Albert Bohrmann. Horst, who died in 1999, left many full career images of a full career to photograph models, clothing and actresses, creating beauty imaginary that can now be seen closely in a display in the City of Dreams (COD), organized in conjunction with Albert Museum London. The show is called “Horst: Style Photographer” [Horst: Photograph of Style] and was inaugurated this Wednesday, revealing the work of this photographer over 60 years. Quoted by a COD statement, Duncan Forbes, director of photography of the London V&A Museum, another of the partners in the organization of this exhibition, spoke on the eclectic side of the work of Horst P. Horst, and can be seen in this show. “From the iconic covers of [magazine] Vogue to the impressive color impressions, Horst's work personifies timeless elegance - a celebration of beauty, posture and artistic accuracy. City of Dreams, with its rich fusion of fashion, design and contemporary art, perfectly reflects the spirit of Horst's work. Horst legacy with a new and demanding audience, ”he said. The exhibition presents a selection of the most representative works of Horst's work, divided into five central themes: “High Couture”, “Surrealism”, “Color Fashion”, “Living with Style” and “Stage and Scree”. According to the same statement, it reveals the “serene elegance of the Parisian couture” and the “bold surrealist explorations”, not forgetting “the pioneering color photography to the vivid portraits of cinema icons”. All of this is up to an “exhibition that offers a rich and multidimensional view of the Horst artistic universe”. Chinese photography In addition, the public will be able to see a special section entitled “Tribute to Horst”, which features works by five influential Chinese photographers, namely Hai Feng, Nick Yang, Trunk Xu, Wu Zeng and Yuangui Mei. This part offers “a glimpse of Chinese fashion photography of the last thirty years, showing its rich cultural dialogues and artistic advances”, which “captures the fascinating interaction between tradition and modernity, oriental and western aesthetics, as well as timeless elegance and contemporary innovation”, highlights Cod. According to the same note, Horst P. Horst is widely considered one of the most influential fashion photographers of the twentieth century, famous for its masterful use of light and meticulous composition. His creative career lasted more than six decades, shaped by artistic movements such as surrealism and the rise of color photography. Its work is known for dramatic tension and artistic depth, providing incomparable aesthetics that remain unparalleled. Horst has also captured some of the most legendary figures in art, literature and fashion - including Coco Chanel, Salvador Dalí, Marlene Dietrich and Andy Warhol - leaving behind an unforgettable legacy. Tim Kelly, president of COD, said, about this exhibition, that "it is a fundamental step in our view of integrating art into everyday life." "The lasting elegance and the innovative creativity of Horst photography are perfectly aligned with the philosophy of our brand. item.title: Wang Yi exhorts European Union to avoid confrontation
item.description: Chinese diplomacy chief Wang Yi yesterday warned his European homologous against the risks of confrontation, at a time when Beijing seeks to affirm himself as a reliable partner, compared to US volatility. During a meeting held on Wednesday in Brussels, with the head of European Union diplomacy, Kaja Kallas, Wang Yi argued that China and the EU “should not be seen as opponents for their differences, nor seek confrontation due to their disagreements,” according to a statement released yesterday by his ministry. The day before, Kallas argued that Beijing should no longer threaten European security, pointing out alleged cybers, interference in democratic processes and unfair business practices. "Europe faces several challenges," said Wang Yi, adding that none of them, "in the past, present or future," was caused by China. Alternative via Chinese diplomacy head sought to introduce his country as a counterweight to Donald Trump's administration, which threatened to impose widespread tariffs on European imports. “The path followed by the United States should not be used as a mirror of China,” said Wang. "China is not the United States," he said. According to the statement of the Chinese Foreign Ministry, both sides also addressed international issues such as the War in Ukraine, the Israelo-Palestinian conflict and the Iran's nuclear program. Beijing and Brussels should act based on “mutual respect,” defended Wang Yi, appealing to a more “active and pragmatic” European policy in relation to China. Wang also met on Wednesday with the President of the European Commission, Ursula Von Der Leyen, and Belgian Foreign Minister Maxime Prevot. Wang told both parts that China and EU should “defend multilateralism and free trade” and cooperate over global challenges such as climate change. The Chinese diplomat now goes to Germany and then to France, where he will meet with French Foreign Minister Jean-Noël Barrot, who visited China in March. These visits precede the China - EU Cimeira, which will bring together in Beijing Chinese President Xi Jinping and several senior European responsible.

The handwriting brushes made had their heyday during the Yuan Dynasty and are still considered among the best in all of China. Four steps are required to manufacture the HU brush, and the coat of the rabbit, the fingernail and the goat hair is used. After the fat is removed with tire juice, the hair is cut into equal sizes and enter a solution to clean them. They are then united at the base with arabic gum and after drying, united with a tile that unites them to the bamboo. With the brush made in its structure, the other phase of the process is passed. This wire that goes through the hair, on a lap gives the cone shape and also serves to remove the excess of the agglutinator papa. With extreme patience and skill, the brushes are clean, rounded, creating a tip, with good elasticity. Then the brush, ready, passes to the hands of another employee, where in the bamboo cable are recorded the characters Tian Kuan Trade Mark, which replaced the old “double goat” brand. The goat hair (HAO) brushes (HAO) are soft and serve to write small characters, rabbit hair are hard and those of the fingernail are between the two, with great elasticity for the handwriting of large characters. Sometimes a mixture of different hair is made, using those of other animals. There are brushes of all kinds of sizes, serving some to paint and others to call. The best for Chinese handwriting are the rabbit and goat hair mix. HU brushes were widely used in the imperial court. In the other part of the museum is the painter's room Zhao Mengfu with its utensils and some works, where the recorded stones are not lacking. Although the museum has a sales section, after leaving the museum and already on the street, a set of stores is dedicated to the sale of products for Chinese painting. In two paintings in the British museum that are attributed to him he is a servant in the middle of the forest, carrying a book in his hand (vertical roll, 99.6 x 29.2 cm) paint), in another a literate with his hands hidden by the cold walking in a snow-covered bridge towards a pavilion. The name given to the painting is: reading, alumiassed in the reflection of the snow. Together, the title and the two paintings seem to allude to a story referred to by Liu Yiqing (403-444) in Shishuo Xinyu, "new account of the legends of the world", about the historical figure of Sun Sheng (c.302-373) that from the most tender childhood to old age was always seen with a book in hand and so poor that at night, the reflection of the reflection of the winter. Moonlight over the snow to illuminate your reading. An example of persistence of the desire to know certainly appreciated by literati, but also remarkably by an Emperor of the Yuan Dynasty who reigned twice, named Tugh Temur (1304-1332) known as Wenzong. And that, being a foreign, cultivated the arts, customs and traditions. From their efforts to impose local culture on the Mongoral rulers, the creation of Kuizhang Ge would be highlighted in the spring of 1329, the “Star of Literature Pavilion Academy”, which among other activities such as the compilation of classical texts also appointed literati capable of recognizing, studying and commenting on works of art. Some were painters, like a literate from Zhejiang. Ke Jiusi (1290-1343) was one of those scholars (Boshi) of the Kuizhang Pavilion of which today can be read the comments on paintings and caligraffes of ancient masters such as Jing Hao (c.855-915) or Jiang Shen (c.1090-1138). In their own paintings, intuition in the composition of the landscape is notorious, which you see an example in the Mustard Garden Manual. Or in a vertical roll where two high -sided Bambus stems painted for the 'hidden virtue pavilion' (Qingbige, paper on paper, 58.5 x 132.8 cm at the Palace Museum in Beijing). In these two rods that grow along with solid stones and when climbing cross, and in which he applied the rigor of the discipline of handwriting, he will have mirrored the will of the court to follow the great lonely masters like Wu Zhen.

item.title: WHO | Study reveals that one in six people in the world feels
item.description:
A World Health Organization report states that loneliness is a growing problem. Based on a study conducted between 2014 and 2023, the document concluded that one in six people in the world feel alone, with emphasis on young people from 13 to 29 years old. The Southeast Asian region has, however, less problematic values
More and more is spoken of the devastating impact of loneliness as a potentializing cause of diseases. This time, a report from the World Health Organization (WHO), released on Monday and carried out by the Social Connection Commission, brings data on the problem, concluding that one in six people say he feels alone, a state that is not synonymous with being alone. Moreover, the problem is greater in younger ones, because one in five says it feels alone, which shows that one fifth of the world's population between 13 and 29 years old says it feels loneliness. The study, entitled “From Solitude to Social Connection - tracing a path to healthier societies: WHO Commission on Social Connection Commission”, focuses on 2013 and 2024, thus encompassing the pandemic, a period when most of the world populations faced confinement periods, some of them alone in their dwellings. The study was sent to journalists from 194 WHO member countries, and the data were dealt with in line with other works already done on the subject and with the support of experts from around the world, including from China. Bin Yu, from the Medical College Tianjin University, was one of the project participants. The report points out that between 2014 and 2023 "it is estimated that 16 percent of people around the world-one in six-felt loneliness," something that "affects all ages and regions." However, it is a “more common feeling among adolescents and young adults”, with a rate of 20.9 percent of young people between 13 and 17 years old, while the rate reduces slightly to 17.4 percent in the case of young adults from 18 to 29 years. The feeling of loneliness "decreases with age", and is also "more common in low-income countries, where almost one in four people (24 percent) claimed to feel lonely." The WHO study also points out that “the highest rates are in the WHO African region”, with 24 percent; Following the regions of the eastern Mediterranean (21 percent), and in Southeast Asia this feeling is less felt by respondents, registering only 18 percent. "The European region has the lowest rate, with about ten percent," says WHO, which distinguishes loneliness of social isolation. In this field, “data is more limited”, but the isolation of the elderly stands out. "Estimates suggest that 25-34 percent of the elderly are socially isolated," it is data on the years between 1990 and 2022. When it comes to adulthood, from 30 to 59 years, the percentage of people who feel only low to 15.1 percent, and in people 60 years or older, with 11.8 percent. Regarding gender, “estimated rates of loneliness in women and men are similar (16.1 and 15.4 percent, respectively), with the highest estimated differences between adolescents (24.3 percent between women and 17.2 percent between men) and the elderly (13 percent between women and 9.9 percent among men)”. Who else feels The report states that nowadays “social disconnection is widespread in all regions and in all age groups”, with consequences that are “serious and underestimated, affecting mortality, physical and mental health, well-being, education, economy and society in general”. "Its widespread occurrence and its serious consequences make it a serious issue of global public health," it is mentioned. And who feels more alone? The WHO highlights “marginalized groups”, namely “people with disabilities, lesbians, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, queer (or sometimes in question) and other individuals (LGBTIQ+) and migrants”. These people “are more likely to feel loneliness and isolation than other groups”, making it the caveat that “previous data are too limited to determine whether social isolation and solitude rates have increased or decreased”. In the case of disabled people, scenarios persist such as being unable to “access social facilities and take advantage of opportunities due to physical barriers in buildings, limited access to transportation and lack of affordable information and communication, while others face structural stigma that limits their job opportunities or other sociocultural barriers that lead to lower level of education, less stable relationships and more precarious housing conditions”. "Many factors" are identified that lead people to feel alone, namely "modernization, industrialization and technological changes", and may be "responsible for what, often, it is presumed to be an increase in social isolation and loneliness, but most remain without proof." "We know that certain factors increase the risk of individuals suffering from social disconnection. These include poor physical or mental health (especially depression), personality traits such as neuroticism, not having a partner or being single, living alone and characteristics of the built environment, such as poor access to public transport. The impact of digital technology is not yet clear, but experts recommend caution, especially to protect the mental health and well-being of young people." study. The WHO highlights, throughout the text, how it is difficult to quantify feelings of loneliness, being relatively recent this type of definitions and, above all, differentiation between the feeling of feeling alone and being effectively only. The report includes testimonies from people from various countries and cultures that describe that, even though they are with a partner or friends, they feel alone in a scenario caused by many factors. In the case of young people, "the realization of high loneliness rates between adolescents is consistent with the results of previous research, although the result may be subject to both developmental and methodological considerations." “As loneliness results from a perceived discrepancy between real and desired or expected social connections, the highest rate in adolescence can be due to higher expectations of social connections during the development phase, which is marked by significant emotional and psychological changes. The elderly report comparatively greater satisfaction with their social relations. According to these estimates, the elderly have the lowest loneliness rates, which contradicts previous studies that enhanced the elderly as the age range with some of the highest rates. This may be due to the limited availability and quality of the previous data on the elderly, ”is explained. The study highlights, however, that it is “possible that the prevalence of loneliness is greater among adults over 80 or older”, which is a “consistent conclusion with previous studies, in which there was a distribution in the form of 'U' of loneliness among older adults”. More than 800 thousand deaths We are in an era where so -called social health is at risk, being considered by WHO as "a vital but often neglected, health, as essential as physical and mental health." "Social relations can reduce the risk of disease, increase life expectancy and strengthen the fabric of communities and society. Social relations improve life, giving us meaning and a feeling of belonging," it is also read, being mentioned that today loneliness affects one in six people worldwide and causes "about 871,000 deaths annually (2014-2019)". "New estimates suggest that loneliness alone may be responsible for about 871,000 deaths a year. The economic cost of these comprehensive impacts on society is just starting to be understood. Estimates suggest substantial costs for employers, health systems and individuals. Stronger social connections provide important protection in health, social and economic domains," he reads. The report points out that many of these issues only now begin to be perceived and analyzed. "This has probably been happening for years, but the pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the growing concern for digital technology has brought more attention to the issue, including governments," he is explained. The WHO also points to a correlation between poverty or low income and the feeling of loneliness. "In general, the lower the performance group in a country, the higher the loneliness rate. It is estimated that low-yielding countries have the higher (24.3 percent), followed by the medium-low yield countries (19.3 percent), medium-high performance countries (12.1 percent) and high-performance countries (10.6 percent)," can be read. Despite some worrying scenarios, WHO leaves some suggestions and even says that "there is hope" to get around the problem. "There are effective strategies for promoting social connection and these must be expanded," for example, by the "regular monitoring of the prevalence of social connection, social isolation and solitude at the global, regional and national level." This monitoring should be viewed as "a high priority", allowing "to track progress and measure the impact of strategies to deal with the issue." It is also suggested the “international development and adoption of reliable measuring instruments, interculturally valid for social connection, social isolation and loneliness”, and as a priority ”should be viewed the creation“ of an instrument to measure social connection, as conceived in this report: in the three dimensions of structure, function and quality ”. The study was based on reference documents on global and regional estimates of the prevalence of loneliness and mortality due to loneliness, “the first of this type”; a global review of political documents; Network mapping and analysis, the inclusion of 64 experiences experienced by people in relation to social connection, social isolation and loneliness, as well as “high quality evidence, prioritizing systematic revisions, meta-analysis and large-scale multinational studies”, without forgetting the experience of the WHO technical advisory group itself, “composed of 20 renowned global experts”.

“For us there are no barriers between Portugal and China. We are 365 days here and there.” This is the way the objectives of the team that is behind the Portugal Pavilion present at the Euro-Asia National Commodity Pavillion are presented in Chengdu and which is managed by two partners: Yinhui Tui and Ângelo Freitas de Sousa. The two realized that the Shanghai zone had reached a saturation point in the trade of products and that it was necessary to go more to the interior of the country to try to sell things as Portuguese as wine, cod or olive oil. HM talked to Yinhui Tui about this project on the fringes of a lunch in Lisbon by the Friends of the New Seda Route Association, chaired by Fernanda Ilhéu. The event served precisely for Yinhui Tui to present the objectives of the Portugal Pavilion and try to capture business interests. “This is a very important market for Portuguese products. In China we have separated the country [in commercial terms] in four markets. We have the region of Beijing and Shanghai, which we call 'Yangtze River Economic Zone', and 'Pearl River Economic Zone'. The fourth zone is composed by the cities of Chengdu and Chongqing and which is a new economic area established in 2020. Portuguese have a lot of potential in these markets, ”he said. The entrepreneur recalls that the marketing of Portuguese products is still below the one that is done by French, Spanish or other countries, but when the Chinese buyer discovers wine or olive oil, he is surprised. "In Shanghai, for example, some customers already have their opinion on French or Australians. But many think that Portuguese products have more quality," said Yinhui Tui, noting that in the area where the Portugal Pavilion operates in Sichuan province, "people are a little more conservative and prefer to try, prove and feel before buying." "Our pavilion is next to the French pavilion and we often see customers opt for French wine. But when they go through our pavilion, they see our brands and ask what we have. When they realize that we have cheaper wine compared to French, they are surprised and say it is better, and then buy." This responsible explains that the population in the fourth economic zone is 130 million people, much more than the number of people living in the Iberian Peninsula. "Then I think it's a market with a lot of potential," he said. The Role of Lusosino Yinhui Tui and Ângelo Freitas de Sousa created Lusosino that it acts as the managing entity of the pavilion, which was born “with the intention of promoting Portuguese products in the Great Market of China”. Thus, there is a “showroom” of very Portuguese products, representing some brands known as is the case of Vieira crackers, Esporão wine, Sal Marnoto, the Prisca jams or Vista Alegre, among others. It is in this pavilion that "exhibitors display the best products, buyers discover trends and where they both find the conditions to realize business." Moreover, Lusosino, through this pavilion, helps Portuguese entrepreneurs in marketing campaigns and in the best way to contact potential Chinese customers. Specifically, Lusosino promises to perform “producer and brands records, commercial representation, market analysis, market support and preparation, among other services”, reads on the website. However, and according to Ângelo Freitas de Sousa to HM, there are many obstacles to putting Portuguese products in China. “[The Chengdu and Chongqing zone] has the advantage of being a growing market that is not overloaded with exporters and has no addictions as happens in the Shanghai zone. It is a very large market and where there are many producers.” By addictions, the entrepreneur refers to “competition” from other countries and buying habits of Chinese customers, who are faster looking for products from other nationalities than from Portugal. "There are habits of certain brands that are implemented and people don't even look at others or experience them." The Portuguese Pavilion project began with an idea of ​​Ângelo Ferreira de Sousa, who has a Chinese wife who helps him in the business. “I met Yinhui Tui, he liked Portuguese products, we were friends and then we ended up joining energy,” he said, explaining that the interior of the country is still knowing foreign products, not just Portuguese. "The Shanghai zone has nowhere to grow and this is a growing economic zone. There are many factories that are moving to Chengdu, so there will be more development," he said. Absence of marketing The Portuguese entrepreneur regrets that the Portuguese authorities have given little support to the project, except for any follow -up by AICEP - Agency for Investment and Foreign Trade of Portugal. "All the investment was made by us and we have not had a lot of support. We had some help from AICEP, but nothing special. We do fairs, the showrooms, to prove and know our products in major cities," said Angelo Ferreira de Sousa. The entrepreneur also regrets that, despite the list of hundreds of years between Portugal and China, there is still flaws in the commercial strategy for the export of Portuguese products in the country. "The Spaniards are much further ahead than us," he said. Regarding the role of Macao as a platform, the entrepreneur says it is equally difficult to bring products from Portugal to China or Macau to China, due to lack of customs agreements and little flexibility. "It is not because we call Macau that I can, for example, putting sausages, cod or preserves in China, or other Portuguese products. To pass from Portugal to Macau is easy, but it is no longer so easy to take after Portuguese products from Macau to China. We have not been able to do much through Macau, but we have not sought much," he said. At the presentation in Lisbon, Yinhui Tui advanced some figures behind the construction of the Euro-Asia National Commodity Pavillion, and help to understand their size: about 70 billion euros of investment and a space of 300,000 cubic meters. The Portugal Pavilion does not only do contact sessions or fairs: if a businessman wants to leave tons of products there, he can do so. Then the pavilion is in charge of distribution through several areas of China. “In the southern market, closer to Macao, there is a lot of competition in some areas, so it should be betting inside China,” said Yinhui Tui, referring to the potential and factor novelty that exists in some areas of the country regarding commerce.

item.title: Coloane | Filipe Afonso launches work that highlights the importance of staff houses
item.description:
The latest book by Filipe Afonso, coordinator of the Architecture course at the University of São José, looks at a housing model at risk of disappearing, but can be seen in Coloane, or in old fishing zones of Hong Kong. “Coloane Grammar” presents alternative solutions for the reuse of these houses and their classification as a heritage
Taking the idea of ​​grammar that names the book, what are the main terms or concepts around Coloane, its tradition and preservation that can enumerate? The “grammar” of the book introduces the concept of vernacular architecture, which reflects the knowledge of the informal, local construction and the maritime identity of this Coloane community. It addresses the assets at risk, proposing a method of cataloging existing houses, this digital method, which establishes a dialogue between tradition and modernity to preserve this cultural landscape. What concrete proposals are suggested in the book for the protection and preservation of Coloane's stilts? The book proposes (indirectly) the classification of stilts as a heritage to give them legal protection. By cataloging existing stilts, the book contributes to preserving the memory of this type of architecture and a broader discussion about its possible protection. How could we reuse the stilts taking into account these specific ways of life and the economic diversification that the government wants to achieve? The stilts could be reused for experience tourism, or centers of cultural interpretation, valuing local history. They can be transformed into creative and artistic spaces or in fact propose new wood buildings along the water line, with various uses and that can generate value to the Coloane community, contributing to Macao's cultural and economic diversification. Why approach Coloane and the stilts? How did this project come about? Coloane and the stilts were approached by their architectural and cultural uniqueness, representing a threatened memory and identity of Macao. This assets at risk has a significant potential. The project also emerged from the gap of scientific knowledge about these structures and the urgent need for documentation, consolidating itself as an academic-scientific investigation. In the Asian or Southeast Asian context, are the coloane stilts or not unique in architectural terms? Water constructions are common in various Asian countries, Coloane's stilts are not a unique case in terms of existence. See the example, in Hong Kong, of the well-known Tai o village, but are unique in their specific context. Its architecture is the reflection of local regional influences and materials, adapted to the history of the evolution of Colona's fishing community and the development of Macao. Its value lies in its particular architectural language and its persistence in a rapidly transformed urban environment. What is the story behind the emergence of stilts? Are you associated with Coloane piracy reports, for example, which refer to the early twentieth century? The stilts emerged as a practical and functional solution to the sea -related way of life, allowing sea access, tidal protection and efficient use of space in coastal areas. Piracy reports in Coloane were not the direct cause of their emergence. Shapes are essentially the response of an informal architecture of local communities to adapt to the maritime environment. Museum Idea on Coloane Stop Stand since 2017 The need for preservation of coloane stilts is not a recent idea. Between 2017 and 2018, the Directorate of Tourism Services proposed the creation of a museum entirely dedicated to the stories of these dwellings arranged in Rua dos Navegantes, but the project was being postponed for legal reasons. In 2018, the Tribuna de Macao newspaper (JTM) published an article where it referred precisely the absence of “legal foundations” for the construction of new infrastructure in the Maritime area of ​​Macao, something that has changed, however, given that the MSAR passed, from 2018, to include in its jurisdiction the management of 85 square kilometers of maritime zones. Last year alone, the executive's plans for the creation of a “functional maritime zoning”, “maritime areas” and other related laws, and a concrete decision on what will be made on what will be made on the stilts. Both zoning and plan will be defined for a temporal period by 2040. One of the objectives of the executive is environmental and ecological preservation, as well as certain experiences of the population. One of the points of the public consultation report speaks of “optimizing ocean exploration modalities according to Macau's development needs; coordinating the use of sea in production, daily life of the population and ecology” and performing “intensive and economizers uses to realize the rational allocation of maritime resources”. In 2018, according to the JTM, STD assured that it would be necessary to “wait for the publication of the maritime area and administrative regulation on the administration of the use of maritime zones” and only then could you think of the planning of the museum. HM questioned STD of this article, and until the closing of this edition, obtained new clarifications. A gradual development In a master's dissertation in architecture, defended in 2023 at the University of Coimbra, Ana Rita Rodrigues made the study of the “Evolution of Macao Territory-Aterros and Urban Design in the Taipa and Coloane islands”, and concluded that “Portuguese occupation in the islands of Taipa and Coloane brought improvements in infrastructure, safety and village organization”. In the late nineteenth century, "there were already, in the islands, schools, hospitals and basic infrastructure, promoting the economic growth of the region." Referring to the existence of stilts “used for the construction of fishing and housing boats for fishermen, naturally facing the river”, in a coloane zone composed “by precarious housing of one or two floors, unlike the type of common housing found in mud or macao, which was more focused on high development”. The author also points out that “development was slower” in Coloane, as well as the absence, on both islands, of “a unified general plan and the need for better urban planning to ensure a cohesive and sustainable environment”.

item.title: Cape Verde | Évora family, between Macau and the rest of the world
item.description:
Tomorrow are 50 years of Cape Verde's independence, the country from which the first levada of the Évora family came out in the 1940s, towards Macao, where he won roots. Nowadays, only one member of the family remains in the territory, the cardiologist Mário Évora
There were once a dozen Évoras in Macao, where they arrived in the 1940s, but only Mario Évora resists, with the family repeating the migrations that mark both Cape Verde and the Macanese. "We have been between eight and ten Évoras in Macau," Sports Medicine expert Humberto Évora told Lusa from Lisbon, where he has lived since he renovated. The maternal grandparents of Humberto (the last of the family to be born in Cape Verde) and Mário (the first to be born in Macau) arrived in the east in the late 1940s, with five of the couple's six children. A year later, the daughter who had stayed with her husband in Cape Verde came to Macau, already with baby Humberto. The initial plan was for two years, but the couple ended up three decades and have three more children: Mario, Rui and Maria Helena. In 1971, it was the turn of Humberto and Mário to leave to study medicine in Lisbon, but not without a great fright linked to the colonial war that had lasted a decade ago. "As we went to the university we could postpone military inspection, but the papers did not come from Macao and we risk being considered refractory," said Humberto. The situation resolved, but Mario admitted to Lusa the fear of the mobilization. "We had this persecution, we had to go through the year not to go with the sides in the war," he explained. “The Shock” in Lisbon Upon arrival in Lisbon, “we were soon welcomed and integrated into the Cape Verdean student community,” said Humberto, at a time of student agitation and politics. "There were periods when it was almost daily, manifestations of students against the regime, the shock police enter the canteen inside and give some suckling," said Mario. Humberto admitted that "it was a shock, for those who came from Macau, where there was little political culture and the colonial war was seen as a struggle against terrorists." In a summer, the young man, who was integrated into a Cape Verdean group of intervention music, left with a friend "to the overseas ride out of guitar on his back." “I always remember the first time in France, that I saw the colonial war described on the contrary on television, the struggle for the liberation of a colonial power of occupation,” said Humberto. Independence When the two brothers finished the medical course, the independence of Cape Verde, on July 5, 1975, led them to the root return. "There was a movement of many of our colleagues to contribute to a new country, which was beginning to take the first steps," said Mario, then a formed cardiologist. Also because, recalled Humberto, some of the friends of Lisbon had, however, became members of the Government of Cape Verde. "There was this possibility, but the return to Macao, a place where it had spent so long, was natural," he explained. “I was born in Cape Verde, I spent part of my life in Portugal, I grew up in Macao, I am also Macaense. I am a citizen of the world,” said Humberto. Macanese are a Euro-Asian community, most of which Lusodescendants, with roots in Macau, although many have emigrated, due to the economic situation or fear created by the transition from Portugal Administration to China in 1999. From the Évora brothers, Rui, engineer, left before the transition to Cape Verde, where he even worked on the project of the Hotel-Casino that Macau's businessman David Chow built on the beach, but was inaugurated. The younger sister, Maria Helena, a documentary science expert who has even worked in the Macao Historical Archive, is currently in the City Council of Oeiras. The children “are all out” between the United Kingdom, Cape Verde and Portugal, said Mario. "Now the world is smaller and it is going where there are opportunities," he said. Humberto also faces migrations "as a natural process, not only for Cape Verdeans, but even to the Macanese." Nothing that has prevented the two brothers from keeping their ties with the archipelago. Humberto divides the time between Portugal and Cape Verde, and has been the official doctor of Cape Verdean sports for decades to the main international competitions. Mario was one of the founders-and president for ten years-of the Macau-Cabo Green Friendship Association. "We had here Ildo Lobo, Tito Paris, and my cousin," said the cardiologist, before taking a break and adds, with a smile: "Cesaria Évora."

item.title: Teaching | I was entering local schools, but resources are scarce
item.description:
The government has been betting on the introduction of artificial intelligence in territory schools, but with a few hours in the curriculum. In addition, schools complain of few resources to meet government goals
Macao schools have integrated artificial intelligence tools (AI) in classrooms, such as smart paintings and linguistic models, but some teachers warn that most are not prepared to comply with outlined policy for the sector. After classes, students at Pui Va Secondary School remain in the classroom, distracted to explore a smart condition. These staff - explains Ruan Zhan Teng, school teacher at the school - act as interactive projectors and are used as soon as the first year, to write, watch videos or participate in classes with digital media. "In the third year, students begin to learn to identify artificial intelligence in everyday life, basic programming and photos and videos generated by AI," the computer teacher added to Lusa. The change took place in 2024 and is stipulated in the law: AI should be included in primary education (with a workload of 17 hours and 20 minutes per year), from 7th to 9th grade (19 hours and 20 minutes) and from 10th to 12th (18 hours and 40 minutes). Despite the requirement, Andy Chun Wai Fan, professor and director of the University of Macao Information and Communication Center in Education, Note that schools face two obstacles: lack of resources and faculty formation. “Some schools have only one information technology teacher,” said Fan, also referring that institutions generally have computer classes only once a week. Do not update Pedro Lobo, a teacher in this area, with 30 years of experience in the territory, including at the Portuguese School of Macau, is concerned about the lack of training. "Most teachers are already a certain age, they have not grown with this new technology ... So the mindset is still short of all this evolution, and change is being so fast that it can hardly follow," explained the Portuguese. Education authorities require teachers 30 hours of annual IA training, however, Pedro Lobo considers not sufficient. Although this year has already studied almost 40 hours, the teacher says he is "little prepared". Regarding this government policy, Andy Chun Wai Fan also remembers that it is required to schools that address ethics, innovation and collaboration in the domain of AI, although it fits the institutions the creation of the manuals themselves. “We do not have a manual about what to teach (…), each school has its own ideas about what to do with its students,” wolf reacted, explaining that he teaches “transferring AI to school work”, either through image generation, small game development, AI ethics approach and copyright issues. Since 2021 at PUI VA In a different record, the Pui Va Secondary School, which introduced AI in 2021, assumes to be “well prepared” to “the change”. The institution spends about two million patacas a year on AI tools, employs seven information technology teachers (IT) and hired a university professor in Beijing to support. “We want students to be able to use artificial intelligence to identify problems and solve real -life problems,” noticed the IT Office Director of Chinese educational establishment, Chong Wai Yin. Here, students work, for example, with programming languages ​​(Python, Tencent, Iflytek), and AI models such as Deepseek and ChatgPT, engaging in intelligent city projects, in the first cycle, and in the creation of applications, at a later stage, said Zhao Qihao, former professor at the University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, who taught in Puija VA. “In the first cycle, we developed smart cities, automated houses and AI -powered parking systems (…). In the second cycle, students create mobile applications and sustainable technological projects,” he explained. In April, the Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, LAM, announced that Macao's educational reforms for 2025 will focus on AI and include plans for an intelligent classroom in all schools. The Government of Macao attributed to the school network under the direction of the Directorate of Youth Education and Development Services (DSEDJ) 15 million PATACA for AI software for this academic year. In an email sent to Lusa, DSEDJ stated that the government “attributes great importance” to the teaching of information technologies. "The medium and long term plan for non-higher education (2021-2030) identified 'reinforcement of creativity and technological education' as one of the main directions of development," he explains in the note. However, Pedro Lobo questions the pressure on young students: "Are we seeing children 8, 9, 10 years old to develop applications? Maybe 1 percent is capable. The rest does the best they can. They have classes and homework that never end." Concerned deputies In the last debate of the Legislative Assembly, last Thursday, two deputies, Iau Teng Pio and Kou Kam Fai, linked to education, defended the need for “high quality development of education in Macao”, namely with the bet on AI. One of the suggestions, referred to during the interventions before the order of day, was the reinforcement of the “coordinated development mechanism between education, scientific and technological innovation and talents”, with the increase of “Stem resources [science, technology, engineering and mathematics] and artificial intelligence on basic education, rooting the basis of scientific literacy”. In the debate on the 11th of this month, it was up to Deputy Ma Io Fong to appeal to AI regulation to avoid scams, but also to increase the awareness of society in relation to this new reality. “With the rapid development of technology these days, the use of AI functions is gradually becoming important help for society and residents in daily life and work. However, AI can give rise to illicit acts, especially the worsening cyber attacks and the diffusion of false information.” Also during the period of interventions before the agenda, the deputy asked the executive to “reinforce sensitization and education on the prevention of AI fraud, to sensitize the elderly and young people, emphasizing that the dissemination of false videos generated by AI can be a legal offense with serious consequences”. In this context, the systematic integration of “AI safety knowledge in school curricula and the realization of different awareness and education activities with community associations was requested to increase public knowledge about AI technology and the risk derived for its abuse”. "It is also due, through cooperation between the government, society, schools and the family, to reinforce the ability to respond to information and the internet discourse, allowing to react, clarify and follow up on useful time, when the public faces information that can cause negative influences or be misleading," said Ma Io Fong in the 11th debate.

item.title: History | The MA-chan escape to the colonial and macau
item.description:
The MA-chan family is from Mozambique with Chinese roots, sought its new path in the then colonial Portugal and since 1976 that set roots in Macao. José Manuel Machon, resident in the territory since he was 13, told Lusa the very peculiar trajectory of his family, which reflects many of the family directions taken in the years of war and the end of the Portuguese colonial empire
The MA-chan, the Mozambican family with roots in China, fled twice to communism and twice resumed in colonial Portugal. In 1976, they landed in Macao, where Mozambique's memory had erased with the departure of the Landins, African troops who parked in the territory for decades since 1912. According to a report by Luís Andrade de Sá published in Macau magazine in 1992, and quoted by the blog "Chronicles Macanese", the Landins were in Macao "for about five decades", and "the Chinese never used to their conviviality, suspiciously who had the huge blacks who played a horrible drumsticks while returning the ostensiva. ferocity ”. The term Landim became a reference “to identify all indigenous battalions that passed by Macau”, is described in the same report. Massá Ma-chan went in 1963 to the Namphlam, northern Mozambique Conservatory to register the fifth son, but once again denied this Chinese, with roots in Guangzhou, the transmission of the nickname to descent. José Manuel was the same as his brothers: the nickname Machon, corruption of MA-chan. The identity of José Manuel Machon, embryoly marked by this bureaucratic detail imposed by the then Portuguese Mozambique, is not only a reflection of the colonial past of Portugal, but from the beginnings of Sino-Mozambican relations. “I don't have great confusion, I tried to adapt to life,” he tells Lusa in Macau, where he has lived since he was 13. The grandfather-also MA-chan-was the one who defined that this story began in Africa, leaving China looking for better life, in the starter of the twentieth century, and settling in Nampula, alongside Sharing, a Macua woman, Mozambican ethnic group. Massá, the son -and father of José Manuel -was sent to Guangzhou at 14, to receive formal education there. When he returns to Mozambique, he is a married man with a bullet mark near his left shoulder. In China, he faced the Japanese in World War II and married a Chinese, which he met on the day of the marriage, until, on the threshold of the civil war, which would give victory to the communists of Mao Zedong, fled. He dedicated himself to Nampula to the cucumber of the cucumber-the 'Magojojo'-and the tubar bit, which he exported to Hong Kong. The Great Return However, unable to adapt, the woman returned to Macao with her four children, where she died. Massá returned to marry, this time with a Mozambican - José Manuel came first, Carla later. When the Frelimo flag raised on the mast in Mozambique on June 25, 1975, the MA-chan-headed Macao, with a brief passage in Portugal, where they inhabited a pension paid by the then IARN. “We are nothing returned, because we have not returned anywhere, we are refugees,” says Carla Machon, residing in Portugal. “When my father heard again about communism, he fled,” says his brother, José Manuel. While speaking, bowling balls pack on the floor and travel the track to a new crash. The noise in the center of Bowling Future Bright does not seem to bother this big man, 61, fluent in Cantonese and Portuguese and president of Macao Bowling Club. “This is what keeps me stable. Instead of going to the glasses, I come here,” he notes. For Joseph, independence "it was an open openness, an opening to the world." It doesn't even talk about political reasons, but how important it was to cross half a world until you arrived in Macau. A new life In this page turn, the MA-chan/maachon family came to find, in 1976, a city with little civil presence abroad. José and Carla do not remember other Mozambicans, who began to arrive after independence, many from Portugal. Mong-Há's fortress is an old witness to Mozambique's presence in Macau. Then the Landins, Mozambican soldiers at the service of the Colonial Army were quartered, recalls journalist João Guedes, a scholar in the history of Macao. It is this historical circumstance that baptized the hill of Mong-há of “Mountain of Black Ghosts”. These troops, with the “greatest warrior instinct”, in the expression of Emperor Gungunhana, remained in Macao half a century, until around the 1960s. They were responsible, for example, by the storage of the siege gates, border of the territory with China and recurring incident place. “They passed by and faded as if they had never been,” resumes Guedes, indicating that there was no material heritage attesting this military presence. Not far from Mong-Há, but at the Riquexó restaurant, troops are still there, eternalized in photos hanging on the walls. This serves African chicken, macanese dish, whose origin is still today the target of debate. Two theories: It was created by the Portuguese chief Américo Ângelo, inspired by a trip to Mozambique. Another version realizes that, seeing the African soldiers missing roasted chicken, Americo made the dish. And the memory of macau-moca-mandamous relationships is not complete without evoking the trafficking in leaf. If, on the one hand, it is known that the Portuguese took slaves from the African colonies by settling in the doors of China, in reverse, were also sent via Macao, Chinese to work in Mozambique, often in slavery conditions. The sons were part of a migratory movement from the late nineteenth century, “to develop the Mozambican colony,” explains the professor at Joaquim Chissano University in Maputo, Fatima Papelo, who investigates Sino-Mozambican cooperation. The first group, he says, was sent in 1858 and "consisted of 30 men." More than a century later, in the struggle for Mozambican independence, Beijing supported the Liberation Front of Mozambique (Frelimo) and is one of the first countries to recognize the new sovereign state. In Macao, the reinforcement of the ties was later paid, with the transition from the territory of Portugal to China in 1999. But for José Manuel, Mozambique was always present. The last time it went, tells, visited and cleaned the family campaign, "there at Machamba". "It's a Chinese custom," he explained.

item.title: Elections | “Soldier of Mao” claims innocent and says he was six days unable to take a shower
item.description:
Accused of electoral corruption and having an illegal Mahjong business, Wong Wai Man yesterday returned to the load to cry out his innocence. The president of the Iron and Steel Shipowners Association says he was “provoked” to climb to the roof where he was a few hours, and was six days without being able to bathe or change clothes
The panorama of the legislative elections for the hemicycle already boils. In addition to these elections with the smallest number of candidate lists since the creation of the MSAR, the controversy is installed with the almost candidate Wong Wai Man, who tried to submit his candidacy without success. Also known as the “Soldier of Mao” and “Captain of Macao”, and after being accused of electoral corruption and having an illegal Mahjong business, behold Wong Wai Man yesterday returned to explanations: refuses the accusations that he is targeted, says he was persecuted by the authorities and refers to “torture” how it was dealt with. The president of the Iron and Steel Association was on Monday, several hours on a roof of a house made with a metal plate in the mud, having been rescued by the Fire Department. A solution that says it was “provoked” after being detained by the Judiciary Police (PJ), referred to the Public Prosecution Service and receiving the Commissioner's Call against Corruption (CCAC), which accuses him of having the illegal business. Wong Wai Man explained that, shortly after leaving the CCAC Office in the Nape area, he was intercepted by an employee of this body that alleged the lack of signature in some documents. However, not satisfied with the situation, Wong Wai Man picked up a taxi towards the mud, eventually taking refuge on the roof. "I had no other option, CCAC wanted to chase me to death. So I was on the roof," he explained. Regarding accusations of electoral corruption, man says he is poor and is unable to commit such illegalities. Regarding Mahjong's alleged illegal business, Wong Wai Man stressed that the Association's headquarters in fact has Mahjong tables, but only for the enjoyment of the partners. Regarding the use of money in these games, Wong Wai Man said there was always a sign to say that it was forbidden to be bets on money and that there was, at the association's headquarters, a box for donations, but that was intended for voluntary support of the members to help the association's operation. This is because, according to this, besides being president is also the only one to support all expenses of the Iron and Steel Association, namely those related to income, water and light, given that since 2014 that the entity has not received subsidies. One thing is certain: the association's headquarters will close doors tomorrow due to the end of the lease. Wong Wai Man says that for now, he will not look for a new address for the association because, for now, he has a more pressing subject: looking for a place to live. Wong Wai Man made the association's headquarters to his home. Life lesson Despite having missed the opportunity to submit a list and be a candidate for elections for the Legislative Assembly by Via Direct, Wong Wai Man argued that the most important thing was to participate in the whole process and learn new things. The "captain of Macao" also said that he is dedicated to society of heart and not by selfishness. Your ideal is to do things justly for society, since it argues that traditional associations do not defend the people. Wong Wai Man also told journalists a personal episode to justify their participation in social and public causes. "In 2007 my wife was pregnant and the hospitals convinced her to end the pregnancy because the baby's survival rate would be 50 percent, due to the fact that a fetal anomaly was detected after the exams. I insisted and the government eventually paid the operation worth 70 thousand patacas. So I want to make my contribution to return a favor" to heaven "," he said. Six days without bathing According to the All About Macau newspaper, Wong Wai Man reported that he was still six days without bathing and sleeping, having remained a week missing until he performed with CCAC this Monday. Before he did, he said he was a total of six days detained, which for himself was “torture”, and that in total was all this time without bathing, sleeping or changing clothes. On Sunday, you will have been able to go home. “Last night [Tuesday] I was finally able to sleep well and shower. I was six days without being able to bathe or change my clothes,” he explained. The climb to the roof of the house in the mud was also a form of protest by the way it was treated, he said. The detention took place at dawn last Wednesday, the 11th, between 3 am and 4 am, with the argument that Wong Wai Man would maintain an illegal Mahjong business. It was then that he was detained for 48 hours in a squad in the mud, and was then transferred to the Public Prosecution Service (MP) to continue to make statements. item.title: Elections | At least 32 crimes oblige to serve a prison sentence
item.description:
The electoral law requires the application of effective arrest penalties that may vary between one month and more than 10 years. One of the cases where convicts even need to spend time in Coloane's prison is the crime of public incentive to abstention, blank vote or null vote
The law provides for at least 32 crimes that always oblige to serve a prison sentence. One of these crimes is the public incentive to abstention, blank vote or null vote, which causes a penalty ranging from one month to three years. According to the general rules of the Penal Code, when someone is convicted of committing a crime there is a possibility that the penalty is suspended for a period from one year to five years. In order for the penalty to be suspended, the law determines that the conviction cannot exceed three years in prison. This period is also time usually considered as a reference for the definition of small crime or a crime that is not serious. However, the electoral law, through article 147, abdicates the regime of suspension of prison penalties, which means that the convicts, under normal conditions, will always spend at least one month in Coloane's prison establishment. The law divides the crime in which it abdicates the suspension of penalty into “crimes related to the organization of the electoral process”, “crimes related to the electoral campaign” and “crimes related to suffrage and determination”. The list of crimes related to the organization of the electoral process includes six offenses and in at least five of them the application of a prison sentence is mandatory, as with the person who agrees to be recognized as a candidate when the legal conditions, or when the coercion or fraudulent devices are resorted to condition the will to participate, or not, in a commission, in the designation of the vote in the staff and the decision of the decision A person is a candidate or not to the elections. Election campaign One of the most controversial questions in the elections is the election campaign period and the ban on campaign activities before the legal period, which this year starts on August 30 and extends until September 12. Earlier this week, the chairman of the Legislative Assembly Electoral Affairs Committee (Caeal), Seng Ioi Man, warned that despite not being received complaints about illicit, the authorities are aware of potential infringements. The law provides for seven campaign -related crimes, but most, four in seven, admits the application of a penalty of a fine, so that the prison sentence will not always be applicable. However, in case there is fraudulent deviation correspondence from Caeal, slanderous denunciation of the crimes provided for in this law or electoral propaganda less than 100 meters from the voting assemblies, punishment always undergoes prison for periods ranging from one month to eight years. Broader crimes It is in the section of “crimes related to suffrage and determination” that the law has the largest number of illicit situations, with a total of 23 crimes. Among the 23 illicit, in four, the application of a penalty of fine is allowed, in addition to prison sentence, but only in certain circumstances. In most crimes planned, 18, it is always mandatory to apply a prison sentence that varies between one month and about 10 years and 8 months, depending on the crime committed. Some of these crimes are specific and aim at security forces, as with forced entry at voting assemblies, and voting meeting for fraud at the time of counting the votes. However, there are also crimes that can be committed by any citizen. It is in this category that is the public incentive to abstention, blank or null vote, which causes a penalty ranging from one month to three years in prison. The same can happen when, within the scope of work, someone threatens a worker with a professional sanction for the coercion targeted to reveal his sense of vote, or vote based on this coercion.
